introduction.p:
The rate at which a force does work is called power of that force. That is, if work W_{if} is done over an interval of \Delta t, then,
\text{Power} = \text{Rate of Work} = \dfrac{W_{if}}{\Delta t}.

Since work is proportional to the magnitude of force, more work will be done if you use a larger force for the same displacement. With a larger force, you will have to do more work but you would also get the work done in less time, and, consequently, will have more power.

If force varies with time, then the rate of work will also vary with time. Therefore, we define two types of power - an instantaneous power, to be denoted by P(t) and an average power during an interval t_i to t_f , denoted by P_{\text{av}} .

subsection.title: Instantaneous Power

sidebyside.p:
Suppose a force \vec F acts on an object which is moving with instantanous velocity \vec v at instant t . In duration t to t + \Delta t, the displacment will be \Delta \vec r = \vec v\Delta t. Here we are thinking \Delta t to be small, ideally infinitesimal. Therefore, work during this interval is
W = \vec F \cdot \Delta \vec r = \vec F \cdot \vec v\Delta t.

subsection.p:
We omit the subscriot if from W since the instants will be indistinguishable in the infinitesimal limit. Dividing W by duration \Delta t, and ideally taking \Delta t\rightarrow 0 limit in a Calculus sense, will give us the rate at which work is being done, i.e., the instantaneous power will be
P(t) = \dfrac{W}{\Delta t} = \vec F \cdot \vec v.

As you know that the dot product can be written using magnitudes of \vec F and \vec v and angle \theta between them or in terms of their components, giving us other formulas for the instantaneous power.
P(t) = F\, v\, \cos\,\theta = F_xv_x + F_yv_y + F_zv_z.

subsection.title: Average Power
subsection.p:
The average power is the average of this quantity over an interval.
P_{\text{av}} = \text{Average of }P(t)\text{ over the interval }\Delta t.
If force and velocity are constant, then, averaging is easy to do. Say, both force and velocity are in the positive x direction with fixed magnitudes. Then, the average will be same as instantaneous. Then, by performing the following series of calculations, we can obtain an alternative form of average power, which is very useful in practice.
P_{\text{av}} = F_x v_x = F_x\, \dfrac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{F_x\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{W_{if}}{\Delta t}.
This demonstrates that the average power is the overall rate at which work is being perfomed by the force.

Another way to average the instantaneous power, P(t), is to plot P(t) versus time. The net area under the curve between t_i and t_f will give the net work done during the interval. Dividing that by the interval will give the average power.

The SI unit of work and time gives us the unit of work as \text{J/s}, which is also called Watts and abbreviated by \text{W}. The unit \text{Watts} is named in honor of James Watts, who made critical improvements to early steam engines.

example.title: Average Power and Moving a Machine Faster

statement.p: You push a heavy machinery horizontally across the room for a total distance of 3 \text{ m} with a constant horizontal force of magnitude 250\text{ N}.
(a) If you completed your task in 10\text{ sec}, what would be your average power?
(b) You can complete the task in 5\text{ sec}, if you apply 1000\text{ N}. What would be your average power now?

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Here, we are given information to find the work done by the push.
P_{\text{av}} = \dfrac{W_{if}}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{ 250 \times 3}{10}= 75\dfrac{\text{ W}}{\text{s}} = 75\text{ W}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Your work will be 4\times as much since we have 4\times the force in (a) for the same displacement. But you did that work 2\times faster. Therefore, your power will be 8\times as much.
P_{\text{av}} = \dfrac{ 1000 \times 3}{5} = 600\text{ W}.

example.title: Instantaneous and Average Power of Weight

statement.p: You drop a 10\text{-kg} ball from a 100\text{-m} tall building initially at rest.
(a) Find the instantaneous power at the following instants in time: (i) 0 , (ii) 2\text{ sec}, and (iii) 4\text{ sec}.
(b) Find the average power between t=0 and 4\text{ sec}.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
We will use P = \vec F\cdot \vec v. The force is the weight of magnitude mg , down, in the same direction the velocity, therefore, the dot product will give:
P(t) = mg v.
where v is the speed at instant t . Since the ball is falling freely at constant acceleration of g, we will have
v = g t.
Therefore, the instantaneous power at instant t is
P(t) = mg^2 t = 10\times 9.81^2\, t = 962.36\, t.
Therefore, the instantaneous power at required instants are:
\text{(i) } 0,\ \ \text{(ii) } 1925\text{ W},\ \ \text{(iii) } 3849\text{ W}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
In (a) we found that the instaneous power is
P(t) = 962.36\, t.
Plot this function versus time from t=0 to t=4 and compute the area under the curve gives
P_\text{av} = \dfrac{\text{Area under } P(t) \text{ vs } t}{4\text{ sec}} = \dfrac{962.36\times \frac{4^2}{2}}{4}= 1925\,\text{ W}.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Time Averaging of Instantaneous Power
subsection.p:
The time-average of a function f(t) of time t over an interval from t_i to t_f is defined by the following integral.
f_{\text{av}} = \dfrac{1}{t_f - t_i}\, \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, f(t)\, dt.

We now show that time averaging P(t) given in Eq. yields the result in Eq. . We start with the time averaging given in applied to instantaneous power P(t) .
P_{\text{av}} \amp = \dfrac{1}{t_f - t_i}\, \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, P(t)\, dt, \amp = \dfrac{1}{t_f - t_i}\, \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, \vec F\cdot \vec v\, dt \ \ (\text{def. of }P(t)), \amp = \dfrac{1}{t_f - t_i}\, \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, \vec F\cdot \dfrac{d\vec r}{dt}\, dt \ \ (\text{def. of }\vec v), \amp = \dfrac{1}{t_f - t_i}\, \int_{i}^{f}\, \vec F\cdot d\vec r \ \ (\text{cancel }dt), \amp = \dfrac{1}{t_f - t_i}\, W_{if}, \ \ (\text{def. of }W_{if}),
which was to be proved.

exercise.title: Power to Maintain Steady Motion of a Conveyor Belt Moving with Increasing Amount of Grain

statement.p: Grains from a hopper falls at a rate of 10 \text{ kg/sec} vertically onto a conveyor belt that is moving horizontally at a constant speed 2 \text{ m/s}.

p.p: (a) What force is needed to keep the conveyor belt moving at the constant velocity?
(b) What is the minimum power of the motor driving the conveyor belt?

hint.p: (a) Use F_\text{av}\Delta t = \Delta p, (b) Use P=Fv.

solution.title: a

sidebyside.p: The horizontal force must proivide the impulse needed to increase x component of momentum of the grains. In one second, v_x of 10 \text{ kg} of grains increases from zero to 2 \text{ m/s}. This gives us the momentum change.

solution.p:
Equating x impulse during one sec interval to change in x momentum gives
F\times 1\text{ sec} = 10 \text{ kg}\times 2 \text{ m/s} - 0.
Therefore,
F = 20\text{ N}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
The power of the force will come from the dot product of the force with the velocity. This gives
P = F\,v = 40\text{ W}.

statement.p: You drop a 10\text{-kg} ball from a 100\text{-m} tall building initially at rest. Find the average power during the following intervals: (i) t_i = 0 to t_f = 2\text{ sec}, and (ii) t_i = 2\text{ sec} to t_f=4\text{ sec}.

hint.p: First derive the instantaneous power function of time. then use the time averaging process to obtain the average power.

solution.p:
Above, in , we found that the instantaneous power for a ball dropped from rest is
P(t) = mg^2 t.
Time average of this function will be
P_{\text{av}}\amp = \dfrac{1}{t_f-t_i}\int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, P(t)\, dt = \dfrac{mg^2}{2(t_f-t_i)} \left( t_f^2 - t_i^2\right), \amp = \dfrac{mg^2 (t_f+t_i)}{2} = 481.18 \left( t_f + t_i\right).

(i) We now use the numerical values of the times we get
P_{\text{av}} = 481.18 \times (2+0) = 962\text{ W}.

(ii) We now use the numerical values of the times we get
P_{\text{av}} = 481.18 (4+2) = 2887\text{ W}.
